prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for buying pregnant wife yoga pass for her birthday
My wife is 16 weeks pregnant.  She has a something called hypermesis which is "morning sickness" all the time, even waking up in the middle of the night to vomit.   I told her to ask her doctor for a medical leave so she is currently on temporary disability.  She stays in bed most of the day and only leaves the house to go to the hospital where she gets IV fluids for dehydration/vitamin deficiency.     
I know I always feel better when I exercise and it helps with depression.  I think she is getting depressed because she misses her job.  I think she should leave the house and get some fresh air and stretch, so I got her a yoga pass for her birthday.   I researched local studios and found one that had prenatal yoga.   When she got the email gift certificate while I was at work, she didn't call to say thank you.  When I got home, I asked her if she got the email and she just gave me a look.  I could tell she didn't like my present.  She says she is too sick to do yoga.   Ok, maybe.   She thinks it is a rude present and that I am "tone deaf."  I can get her another present...don't know what.   I don't think my present makes me a bad person, though.   She might feel better soon and want to take yoga classes.  She told her friends about it and they agreed with her that I am being an asshole.  I think it is rude to be so critical of my present.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who bought the yoga pass for his pregnant wife is in the wrong. The wife has hypermesis, which is severe morning sickness. She's on temporary disability and spends most of her time in bed. The husband thought exercise and yoga would help her depression, so he got her a prenatal yoga pass. But she didn't like it and her friends agreed she was right to be upset.

Hmm. So the question is, did he do something wrong? Well, hypermesis is a serious condition. If she's too sick to leave her bed except for hospital visits, maybe yoga isn't feasible. The husband might have good intentions, but maybe he didn't consider her current physical state. Prenatal yoga is generally safe, but if she's severely ill, maybe she's not up for it. He might have thought he was helping, but the gesture was tone-deaf because he didn't realize how unwell she is. 

On the other hand, his intention was to help her mental health. But maybe he should have communicated more about her needs. Did he consider that she might not want to leave the house or feel up to it? The wife's reaction was a look and not a thank you, which suggests she felt hurt. Her friends also thought he was being an asshole. That's a strong reaction, but maybe they're right because he didn't take her current condition into account. 

The husband might have overlooked her actual needs. Even though yoga is good, in her current state, it's not practical or comforting. He might have assumed she wanted to be active when she's actually too sick. So, the mistake is not considering her condition and the reality of her situation. Therefore, he's in the wrong because he didn't take her feelings into account. Answer A.
